 Yeah, great. So, happy to be here with you, speaking a little bit about science fiction
and future. I am Xavier Facelina. I'm the CEO of a company called TechLab. And I work
in securing critical systems and including nuclear facilities. Keep that in mind for
a few seconds. And Nicola is my co-author and is not my co-presenter today. Couldn't
make it to the U.S. is very sad. But I will present for the two of us. So, Nicola is futurist.
I didn't know what was a futurist before meeting Nicola. But it is a futurist. He's a researcher
at the University in France. He's CEO of his own company. And he leads the red team
defense of the French Department of Defense. So, what is the red team? It's not the same
red team as you. It's not about cyber security. It's a team of military, of authors, science
fiction authors, of scenarists, of movie makers, reflecting about the future of the
war and the future of the conflict. So, that's the red team of the Department of Defense.
I was speaking about that with someone yesterday. He said it's the French thing I heard in DEF
CON. So, yes, it's very French to have a red team at the DOD. But Nicola leads this team.
I will introduce us by and introduce the conference by saying a little word about, okay, how we
met and how we have this idea to make this conference. So, we were both of us a speaker at a
conference. It was presenting something on the future and innovation. And I was giving a
talk, an inspirational talk on my own past and personal journey. And in this talk, I was
saying that when I was a kid, I saw this movie, War Games. I was 7 years old and I decided to
be a hacker and to marry Jennifer. Don Juan failed one. Perhaps some of you failed one, too.
But I speak about that and say, okay, War Games was a very moving movie to me, et cetera, et
cetera. And continue my story. And after my talk, Nicola came to me and said, hey, Xavier, you
are one of the living examples of the fact that science fiction drives reality. And I was like,
what? What do you say to that? You didn't figure that you funded and ran a company to protect
nuclear facilities from hacking because you saw a movie when you were 7 years old and that the
threat was just pure fiction. And I was, no, I didn't figure that. It was the first time I
think about that. So, I said, okay. It's very interesting. And a few years later, we decided to
start a research program on hacking in science fiction. And a few months later, like eight
months later, I'm here in front of you. Thank you very much for being here with me. So, it
will be a journey. I will not be conclusive. It's more about introduce you to the usage of
science fiction in innovation and reality. How we can care about science fiction. I think
that probably most of us are a little geeky and like science fiction. But I think that in this
talk, I probably would invite you to consider it like something that is professionally very
accurate. So, let's start the journey by some thing about the science fiction and the
imaginaries. So, first, just to clear the air, this is a scientific domain. So, you can read a lot
of papers or books like the excellent books of David Kirby on the impact of science fiction on the
real world. And how science fiction is pushing the world in a, let's say, not known future, but
in a casted future. So, and there is a feedback loop between science fiction that drove the
innovation. And the innovation that inspires science fiction. And this feedback loop is well
documented in some scientific readings. One of the usage of science fiction is, of course, to raise
the awareness of public politics. There is two main ways of doing that. One is by utopia, by
presenting something that we want to get. And the other one by dystopian. So, by showing
something that we don't want to have. Statistically, we have more dystopia than utopia in
science fiction. Who here never saw this video on YouTube? Okay. So, I will not show the video
because it's a seven minute long video. But I do encourage you to note the term and to look at
this video right after the talk. It's seven minutes. And I swear it's a good idea. So, just wait a
second for the pictures. Three, two, one, new slide. So, now I will spoil you the video. So, it's
about a presentation. A presentation about a company making a weapon and drones. So, the guy is
on stage. He's very happy to present the successful product, the drone. And he's presenting the
new generation, like micro drones. Micro drones capable of escaping the bullets of snipers.
Having a camera, technical sensor, face recognition, like any phone or apps. So, it's very
important when you do some fiction to relate to what exists. Because we can figure that, yes, it's
possible. And of course, some explosive. And then he showed a demo of a surgical strike of the micro
drone killing something. And then he goes on. Example of another surgical strike. Everybody is
happy. Except then, of course, there's the beginning of some accident. Of some terrorism with these
drones. Even in university classroom, targeting specific people that have reposted a video on
social media. Denouncing some government, et cetera, et cetera. So, at the end, we see that it could be
very bad to have this kind of technology. And at the very end of the video, you see, this is for
real. It's in the video. But he's a real professor that explains, okay, guys, we made this movie to
raise your awareness about the danger of such technology. So, that's one usage of science
fiction in reality is to shape innovation, yes. But to shape politics, regulations. I think it's
very important. So, that said, let's talk about hacking. So, we started to look at the core
subject. Like I said, when I met Nicolas, we decided to work on science fiction and hacking. Hacking
in science fiction. So, we said, okay, what is, to clear the air again, what is the
representation of hacking? So, we started to call images, like a lot of images from Pinterest,
Art Station, etc. And we use a tool named PixPlot by DH labs of Yale University to map the images
and to see some cloud, etc., etc. So, what you see behind is the cloud of the representation of
the word hacking. It's very, it was a huge disappointment. It's hacking furniture, like Swedish
furniture. So, when you look at all the pictures of hacking, it's not related with hackers. So, we
look for another word, oh, sorry, no. Another thing that you find, because you see there was
two clouds. One is hacking Ikea furniture. The other is hacking your phone like the 10 features
that you don't know, the super shortcuts that you must know, etc., etc. So, on the internet, the
representation, visual representation of hacking is now not related to hackers. So, we look for
hacker. And this is very, there are strong archetypes of hackers. Of course, the mask of V4FanData
and Anonymous. Of course, the hoodie. It's a must have. And sometimes both, the mask and the
hoodie. Another representation of hacker, it's drawing. And you can see that there is a sort of
pattern sometimes. So, again, strong archetypes. And when we speak about archetypes, we
say that every family of image that we found was quite the same. I mean, it's like four images.
So, we have terminals, we have metrics, and we have some hardware hacking. So, yes, we have
some. If we look for cyber security, we can see padlocks. So, for the lock pickers in the room,
you are well represented. Cyber security is clearly a padlock for the rest of the world. And you
can see some devices, mostly Apple ones and iPhone. And you can see people. Some with hoodies,
and some of them with shirts and suits. That's cyber security. So, it's, again, really, really
caricature. So, the representation of hacking, hackers, et cetera, is a caricature. And this is
an important point in the fact that it's difficult to raise the awareness of the public with a
caricature. So, as experts, we know, for example, that some threats exist, that some risks are
important. And we sometimes fail to communicate that to people. Why? Because the
representation that they have is caricature. So, we are not legitimate, credible, because they
picture us with hoodies and with padlocks. So, that's one of the bias. Some people try to
change that. So, the idea with HP, run a contest to say, okay, please submit some
representation to raise the awareness of the public on cyber security. But without being
caricature. So, I'm just showing you some examples. One is, okay, my other computer is your
monitor. The T-shirt with all your information on you. A picture about what is encryption for
the movies. And I like the one on the right to say, okay, which one is the hacker? All of
them. And hackers can be in any shape, age, et cetera. And so, it's, I mean, it's a try to be
less caricature and to give some space and some imagination to the public to drive them into,
okay, that's the real world of hacking. It's not hoodies and padlocks. And to be clear, I have
hoodies. And that's an interesting point. Because when, I don't know, when it's 3 a.m. and I
can't figure this particular bug. So, I don't, I fail to scan something. I have my hoodie and
you know, I make this move, take a coffee, et cetera. And I am into the character. So, yes,
it's caricature. But it defines me, too. So, I have a hoodie and I feel like, okay, I am in
the hacker community because I dress like that. So, it's a feedback interaction again. So,
let's explore. Because when we saw this caricature representation, we say, okay, now we
have to explore the real science fiction. It was just internet representation, present public
representation, nothing about science fiction. So, we started the real work. And by
real work, I mean that Nicola and his team had to watch and read a lot of him. So, I'm not
judging, but it's not working. I mean, I'm joking. Of course, it's a huge work. So, they
characterized almost 200 entries, reading movies, comics, et cetera, et cetera. It's just
an example of the database. And this database was like that. We can obviously see that we
have a lot of movies speaking about hacking and hackers. Some TV shows and after manga, we
have found one video game about hacking. And all of that were studied by Nicola and his team.
And then, okay, excuse me. So, they looked at a lot of movies and series and they
characterized the thing to see, okay, what is the target? What is the type of attack that has
been done? And, okay. So, I will just try the PDF file after that. So, okay.
So, what's important is to see that these movies, et cetera, et cetera, we have made a
study to characterize all of the attacks in the movie. So, what is the characterization? It's
what type of targets, like military, civil society, private sector, et cetera. And what type
of attacks? Was it just spying, tapping? Was it destroying? Was it modifying things? Okay.
Excuse me. I'll try in the same time to have this. I will need some technical help here to
have the PDF on the screen because the PowerPoint file is crushing PowerPoint. So, while my
savior will try to have the PDF file on the screen, I can show you some of the insights. So,
first of all, in the fiction world, the attacks are very well spread across destroy and erase.
Like one, let's say 25% of the attacks is destroying things in the science fiction. So,
almost 25%, it's spying things. And then you have a little more of sabotage, slowdown. And the
majority is about modifying things, like to influence people, to change that, et cetera. So,
in the science fiction, all the things are, I mean, well spread into this fourth category. So,
and the government is the main target. And then military and civil society. When we, I don't
know if we succeeded. I'm with you, you know. When we went to reality and to study the real
attacks, we studied almost 1,000 attacks with three sources. One is the U.S. concealed
foreign relation database, which is very rich. It's a lot of attacks. Another one was the
cybercrime story data line. And then we've made some interviews to characterize some of the
attacks, et cetera. So, of course, keep in mind that we do have a bias on the reality because
it's declarative. So, on the fiction, we have access to all the data. But on the reality, it's
declarative. So, the data set is not representative of all the real world attacks. Only the
attacks that have been reported. So, almost 1,000 for the reality. And then when we compare
on the same aspect that science fiction attacks, we can see that it's not at all equal. It's
like, I mean, 80% of spying government and spying financial data. It's a very few
destruction, very few influence. So, it exists, of course. But when you look in the proportions,
you have most, I mean, a lot of spying. And the targets, like I said, are more government,
private sectors, and then military. So, what was my curiosity about that is that we were
thinking that, okay, science fiction is super aggressive with the world. When you see a
movie or you look at science fiction, it's like destroying things, killing people by hacking,
et cetera, et cetera. And you don't have that yet in the database of the past attacks. But
when you look closer at the numbers, you see, okay, what are the attacks that destroy
something in the real world that are used for terrorism, et cetera? You find some of these
attacks, and you can find a sweet spot in 2008, let's say 2008, 2010, when attacks become
real world attacks. So, of course, we can have in mind Stuxnet or some pipelines blowing,
et cetera. So, we have a curve of real world attacks that is coming for 10 years now. And
that we start to capture in the databases of real world attacks. So, I think that we are
exposing ourself to what science fiction showed to us for years. And we are doing that because
we are digitalizing things. But anyway, the point is, what can we do now to prevent that?
And is there some solutions in science fiction? I will stop just a second to see if we can
get some sort of presentation back. Sorry about that. Okay. So, like I said, 2008, the
first reported real world accidents due to hacking. So, pipeline blowing. And in 2010,
Stuxnet. So, let's have a quick stop on two examples of physical threats or attacks. Hacking
a nuclear plant or hacking a pacemaker. So, two examples of real world potential attacks
or threats. So, if we're speaking of nuclear plants, interestingly enough, the first
appearance of hacking a nuclear plant in science fiction is quite old. It's like 1984. A movie
called where a college kid hacked into a nuclear plant, et cetera, et cetera. This is a
movie. Actually, I think it's not surprising. Because if you are careful enough, the guys
in the nuclear plant cannot spell conference correctly. It's conference. But anyway, they
managed to hack into it. And we had to wait 2010 to have the first nuclear plant hacking
with Stuxnet. So, in that case, science fiction was very early before we had a nuclear plant.
Before the real world attack and before the real world exposure. The pacemaker case, it's
a little different. Because the first appearance is in reality. In 2008, a scientific paper
showing some potential vulnerabilities in pacemakers. And in 2012, at the end of the year,
2012, there was an episode showing the murder of the vice president with the hacking of
his pacemaker. So, what he's doing now is to gather the ID number of the pacemaker. And look
at 2013, the actual vice president dictionary removed the features of his pacemaker. And he
said publicly that, yes, he saw the TV show and, yes, it's credible and it's an accurate
representation of what was possible. So, he did not read the scientific paper in 2008. But
he saw the episode and decided to remove the functionality. In 2017, there was a
recall of half a million pacemakers to fix, to patch some vulnerability that made the
pacemaker hackable. And in 2018, there was a presentation, I mean at Black Hat, but at
DEFCON 2, about a threat in the pacemakers. So, in that case, the science fiction was lagging
behind the reality. But I think that we can say that the reality reacts to the science fiction
more than the scientific publication. So, for the last part, try to go on a more positive
vibe and to see how we can use the science fiction and study the science fiction to innovate.
So, for the moment, it was a very glimpse on a very quantitative approach. And now, we
will be more of a qualitative approach with an example of an innovation track. So, nothing
really fancy, but let's try. So, as we gathered a lot, lot, lot of pictures and a lot of movies,
et cetera, et cetera, we found that the representation of the cartographic map was
something that was coming very often in the science fiction and very often in the real world.
So, we can see on any vendor site, some cartographic representation of the threats and
attacks, et cetera. I don't know if they know that, but actually, it's from a science fiction movie,
a very great movie in 1970 called Colossus, the Forbidden Project with robots, AI, et cetera.
Very, very great movie, where you can see the threats moving on the map. And so, we ask
ourselves, is it the best representation of cyber threats, this geographical map? Not sure of
that. So, we dig a little bit on geographical representation and we found the work of the
professor about health and about a way of representing pandemics. So, he made this
simulation with a standard representation of a virus spreading on the earth. So, you can look,
it's, I mean, okay, it's blinking, it's red. You clearly see that it's a problem, it's a pandemic,
but we cannot get a lot of information of it. And so, this professor said, okay, let's make the
exact same simulation of a pandemic, but instead of having a cartographic map, let's have a map
of the duration of the flights between airports. So, at the middle, we have the airport,
the start of the pandemic, and then you have all the cities by time of flight airport to airport.
And, of course, he found out that it is useful, because you can clearly predict where the
pandemic will hit and at which stage. So, we get this first thing about cartographic map,
and we continue the work, and we found other work, a scientific work about cartography. This
one is about banks' risk, how to map the risk on the attack from a DAB or from an agency on a
bank. And those guys made something pretty funny to look at. They make this first cartography,
and then they decided to represent geographically with Lego the whole system. So, the DAB, the
bank, the bank servers, et cetera. And at last, they put a little camera on the attacker to see
the point of view of the attacker. And to say, okay, we can see what it can reach easily, what
is hidden behind something, et cetera, et cetera. So, we decided to mix as an experiment. It's not
a real innovation. It's just an experiment. We decided to mix the two representations and say,
okay, what if we picture a cyber attack with a distance by connection and not a map of the
network. With a distance by connection. And we, like in this picture, and we take the point of
view of the attacker, of the point of view of the malware, for example, on the network. And then
we say, okay, perhaps it can look something like that. If you put some VR, it's okay. I will put
my VR lens and then I will go straight into the network and at the place where the malware is
detected and I can say, okay, from here, I can see this system. I can see this one. This one is
protected enough, but I think that I can reach the OT network in one jump or two, et cetera. So,
of course, if we elaborate that, we can draft some information and perhaps we can work with the
team in the SOC to be able to react more efficiently with a typical SOC. I mean, when you
look at the picture of a SOC, it's a wall of screen. Everybody is looking at the screen.
Nobody is talking to each other. It's very strange. So, again, we use the science fiction to
say, okay, in the movies, what are the SOCs? So the first thing that we found out is that the
people are talking to each other. So we designed some draft of an SOC where people sit around
tables. They can see each other. They can have a big screen if needed. And, of course, you can
see the guy on the left with the guy inside the attack that we see previously. He's working
with his teammates. He can send data to the workstation. And he can see what is happening.
And when we are done, when we are here, what we have to do is to get back to reality and to
project something that is tangible, that some people can think about, okay, yes, it's real. It
can be done. So we just try to picture that and say, okay, let's remove the two fancy things
but we can have some screen in the middle. We can have people sitting and people working
together. We can have this guy with this VR lens to work on the SOC. So that is, again, it's
not product. It's not an innovation. It's just a picture of, okay, we can use and we can
wrap up like that. We can use science fiction to see macro tendencies. For example, the
macro tendency that we missed is that the world will be aggressive and the cyber attacks will
convert to real world attacks. It was clearly present in the science fiction and we did not see
that coming in 2008 and 2010. So that's the macro vision. We can use the science fiction on a
more specific vision when we say, for example, for the nuclear plants or for the pacemaker and
to say, okay, if it's coming, what we can do. We saw that we can use it to raise awareness. So
instead of just gathering information for the science fiction, we can produce content. We can
produce movies. We can produce art to raise the awareness of people on the subject. And, of
course, we can innovate because we can figure what kind of threats will come or what kind of
defense we would like to have. So to conclude, I would say that this is a starting project,
a starting research project. So just eight months ago I was sharing the information with you. If
any of you are interested to participate or to know something about, please just ping us or
follow us on Twitter, for example. We will publish soon the information about the group that
will be found like an open research group to dig in this subject of what we can learn about
science fiction, what we can do with science fiction and what we can change in the future, how
we can shape the future of cyber defense. So if you want to watch a movie and work with us on
the project, please give us a word. So thank you. Thank you very much for your presence.
Sorry for the bug in the middle of the presentation. And I think we have some minutes for a
few questions, if there are. Thank you. Thank you very much.
